title: CSS Positioning Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of CSS positioning: relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky

questions.question: What does position: relative; do?
choices: Removes the element from normal flow
Moves it relative to its normal position
questions.explanation: Relative offsets the element but keeps its space in the layout.

questions.question: When you use position: absolute;, what is the element positioned relative to?
choices: The nearest ancestor with a positioning context (non-static)
questions.explanation: Absolute positioning positions relative to the nearest positioned ancestor, or the document if none exists.

questions.question: Which property keeps an element visible while scrolling, but only after reaching a threshold?
questions.explanation: Sticky positioning switches between relative and fixed based on scroll position and defined thresholds.

questions.question: position: fixed; is most useful for:
choices: Elements like floating buttons or headers that must stay visible
questions.explanation: Fixed positioning keeps elements in the same viewport position regardless of scrolling, perfect for persistent UI elements.

questions.question: Why might position: sticky; not work?
choices: Its parent container has no scrollable overflow
questions.explanation: Sticky positioning requires a scrolling container to function - without scrollable overflow, there's no scroll threshold to trigger the behavior.
